title: zelenskys defiant behaviour proves vladimir
story: Zelenskys defiant behaviour proves Vladimir Putin cannot win war in UkraineAs he addressed MPs in the House of Commons and talked about the Russian invasion of Ukraine, Volodymyr Zelensky pointed out he was talking to everyone in the UK, as a fellow citizen of the world.Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky addressed MPs in the House of Commons via videolink Image: PAopinionByBrian Reade:,  Mar |commentsIn a political chamber that has too often witnessed cowardice here was the face of courage. You had to pinch yourself to realise that until very recently our Prime Minister spent every appearance here refusing to admithe’d held parties in his own flat. Yet here was the leader of a major European country being brutally honest about the devastating shelling of flats by an invading army in cities three hours away from the UK on a budget flight.As Volodymyr Zelensky outlined the crimes being unleashed by a “gangster state” the assembled MPs, wearing headphones and grim expressions on the packed benches, gave the big, hushed room the feel of a war crimes court. Hopefully a modern-day Nuremberg awaits Zelensky’s nemesis, Putin. The Ukrainian leader pointed out he was addressing everyone in the UK, as a fellow citizen of the world. And dressed in his trademark green tee-shirt he looked the part. As he gave us a breakdown of the horrors happening in his homeland, with eyes heavy and face drawn, it could have been someone you’d just met talking you through a personal tragedy. If anything encapsulates the Spirit of Ukraine it is this man. If anything says Putin won’t win it is Zelensky’s defiant demeanour. His presence in our parliament, like his message, was simple. It said: “I’m not hiding, I’m not afraid. We will endure.” Other world leaders have addressed Westminster before such as Barack Obama and Angela Merkel. But whereas they felt like they were taking part in some mutual admiration ceremony, this felt real. It felt urgent.  Whenever we turn our TVs on we see voiceless children and pensioners scrambling for their lives, and here was their voice. Here was their living symbol of resistance. Here was a man telling us, from the heart, why we cannot further abandon those innocent civilians who do not deserve their plight. Yet who do deserve our protection. It made you ashamed of the listening government’s pathetic response to the refugee crisis, with the pitul amount of visas they’ve handed out and the bureaucratic hoops they are making desperate people jump through to get them. Zelensky is what we hope we would all be when put under the most intolerable of pressure. Cool and courageous. This former actor is suddenly making speeches on the hoof that the finest dramatists would be proud of. For his British audience he evoked Shakespeare, saying there was no question of whether Ukraine’s fate was “to be or not to be.” It was to be. He pushed the British patriotic buttons even harder when he summoned the spirit of Winston Churchill, vowing to fight the Russian enemy in the fields and in the forests. Johnson gave a knowing smile of recognition when he heard that. Priti Patel sat there smirking by his side throughout, as she does. And when Zelensky talked about dramatically increasing sanctions, Rishi Sunak’s eyebrows twitched as he did the sums.  To hear him speak is to realise how badly Putin underestimated the will of Ukrainians. It’s the sense of calm he projects that has kept his nation going in the face of horrendous oppression. At the end of his -minute speech, during a long standing ovation, some MPs wiped away tears. It was a moving performance which humbled all who watched and gave us hope. Because the longer Zelensky survives and the more he draws standing ovations from parliaments and wet cheeks from millions watching on TV, the more he becomes Putin’s worst nightmare. title: single mum earning 16k pays
story: Single mum earning £k pays off £, debt in  months using p challengeRachael Easter, , from Ipswich, says she was at rock bottom when her marriage broke down and she was left in £, debt with no job - but after starting on a debt-free journey, shes made remarkable savingsRachael was left in £ of debt after her marriage ended Image: MakeTheHeadlinesByTfany WallisJessica TaylorReal Le Features Writer:,  Mar |commentsA single mum who was left in debt after splitting from her husband managed to pay off more than £, debt in  months - with just a £, income. Rachael Easter, , from Ipswich, split from her husband in March  and was left in a dire financial situation, facing eviction from her family home and in £, debt. Worried for her -year-old son Jackaposs future, Rachael says she was at rock bottom after the break up and didnapost know where to turn. She said: I was a stay at home we and mother, with no money to my name. I didn’t have a job at the time. We were at risk of eviction. The thought that I couldn’t put a roof over my sonaposs head because I relied on another being devastated me. For more of the news you care about straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters hereRachael claimed Universal Credit to stop herself and Jack becoming homeless, and received £ a week in food vouchers which was given to low-income families during lockdown.Then, she started looking at her outgoings versus what was coming in every month to try and make a dent in the debt. The debt was from my gas and electric provider, water, bank loan, a sofa, and a credit card, she explained. Rachaelaposs rent is £ per month, plus council tax. She pays £ for water bills and had been paying £ for energy - although this had increased to £. Each month, she would receive £- in Universal Credit payments and every four weeks, sheaposd also get £ in child benefit. While she tried out dferent methods of paying off the debt, Rachael decided she needed to start working, and began offering her services as a self-employed cleaner on Facebook in summer .She charged £ an hour and worked up to  hours some weeks - but in others it could be as few as just five. Her universal credit payments ied depending on how many hours she worked - and last year she earned a total of £, from cleaning, which was topped up to £, with UC. Recalling how she paid of a huge amount of the debt she owed, Rachael said she tried the snowball method. I sorted my household bills first including water, and gas and electricity. I called the companies and with both monthly bills they put my debt on top, she said.Then I used the snowball method to manage it. Which means I paid off the smallest of all the debts first before moving onto the larger debts. Rachael said her motivation for getting the debt paid off on her own was her son Jack - but she worried she was taking on too much at once and had to make huge sacrices. The mum, who doesnapost drive, was so determined to get working that she sometimes walked an hour to and from cleaning jobs. She also started the p challenge, which involved saving a little bit of money every day, starting with a penny. The next day you save two pence, and so on. By the end of a year, youaposll save £. and have a total of £. in savings. She also created online Monzo savings pots for spare money - which she uses for birthdays, Christmas, driving lessons and regular savings. Rachael said: I would move money from my bank to my Monzo pots. Before, I would have just used the money here and there and it would have disappeared. But I’ve been making a conscious effort to put it aside. I’m now also able to give my son pocket money once a week buthe hasnapost done anything to earn it I put it in his Monzo pot to help with a car or deposit when heaposs older. ThenI do an extra cleaning job or have an additional ironing customer, I split what I earn - half onto the debt and half towards my savings. Another way Rachael made up the cash she owed was by selling unused items she had in her house - and thinks this is a great tip for making money quickly. As well as her cleaning job, Rachael set up a side hustle, which she calls her hobby hustle, selling decorated vases with her friend. To keep costs down in her day-to-day le, Rachael draws up meal plans to keep her weekly shop to a minimum and uses vouchers and discounts where she can.While trying to save money, Rachael discovered the debt-free community on Instagram and set up her own page, @getstuffdone_withcoffee to share her progress and top tips.She also uses the page to talk about house cleaning and mental health - and receives plenty of support from her , followers.  I was so embarrassed of my situation and I wanted to improve all aspects of my le so I set up my page, Rachael said. Just  months on from starting her debt-free journey, Rachael had paid of £, of the debt sheaposd accumulated. My house is becoming a home, I have savings, a small amount but more than I have ever had before, debt clearing and a new lease of le, she said, adding sheaposs so proud of what sheaposs achieved. Since becoming more financially independent, Rachael is sure anyone  can manage what she has - particularly single parents. I still have a long way to go but my target for this year  is to become debt free and pass my driving test which will open up more opportunities, she explained. I now have under £ debt left to pay and by the end of the year I will be debt free. As the future is always uncertain with prices of bills and food I am currently looking for a part time job to make sure myself and my boy are secure. ButI can do it, I hope it shows other single parents that they can do it too. title: cops plea prime suspect student
story: Cops plea to prime suspect in student murder case after woman arrestedFarouk Abdulhak, billionaire son of an Egyptian soft drinks tycoon, is wanted for questioning in connection with the killing of Norwegian student Martine Vik Magnussen in London  years agoFarouk Abdulhak has been named as the man suspected of murdering Norwegian socialite Martine Vik Magnussen Image: PAByTom PettorCrime Editor:,  Mar A woman has been held over the unsolved murder of a student as police told the playboy prime suspect: “Come back to face justice.” Farouk Abdulhak, billionaire son of an Egyptian soft drinks tycoon, is wanted for questioning in connection with the killing of Norwegian student Martine Vik Magnussen in London  years ago. Abdulhak, now , left the UK hours after she was last seen and is now believed to live in Yemen with his we and two children. A woman in her s was quizzed by detectives today after being arrested on suspicion of assisting an offender.Det Chief Insp Jim Eastwood, leading the Scotland Yard probe, said: “This matter will not go away. My team and I will continue to seek justice and useall opportunities to pursue him and bring him back. “I’m appealing to Farouk Abdulhak directly: Come back to the UK. Come back to face justice.” Martine, , was said to have left a club in Mayfair, Central London, with him at around am on March , . She had been among a group of students from the Regent’s Business School celebrating the end of exams. Two days later police found her body under rubble in the basement of flats on nearby Great Portland Street where Abdulhak lived. A postmortem gave her cause of death as compression to the neck. create, two six-year-old dogs have been able to explore the outside world for the first time.Six-year-old poodle cross dogs Bella and Lila and were completely shut down when they were taken into the RSPCAaposs care.The charityaposs Martlesham Animal Centre, in Suffolk, took the pair in after their owner signed them over. Kennel supervisor Natalie Wood said: “Bella and Lila had led such restricted, sheltered lives and we believe they’d only had very limited time out of their crates, so theyaposd barely experienced the outside world.to our TeamDogs newsletter for your weekly dose of dog news, pictures and stories. “Their coats were matted and dirty, tangled with urine and faeces. That was a huge milestone for us. “After months of slow and gradual work we had a breakthrough in May when Lila, who’d developed a strong bond with our kennel assistant, Lucy, learned to rush over to her when she arrived at her kennel each morning and put her paws onto her shoulders asto give her a hug. It was a beautul moment.Lila - now renamed Jemima - was adopted by Deborah Turpin and her family, from Suffolk, to live with their eight-year-old retired racing greyhound, Sam. They were looking for another dog after losing their border terrier and spotted Jemima’s profile online. “Her video was heartbreaking and I just couldn’t get her out of my mind,” Deborah said. “What she’d been through was unimaginable and I knew we had to give her a chance. We decided to rename her as we wanted her to leave her old le, and her old name, behind her.” The family collected Jemima in October and set about helping her settle in her new home. “She is an absolute dream, she’s such a superstar,” Deborah added. “She has a wonderful personality and is so affectionate. She rushes up to us every morning to give us a cuddle she obviously has six years of cuddles to make up for! We had no idea we needed a little white curly-haired dog as much as we do! “The most enormous credit goes to the team at Martlesham who helped her after what she went through they instilled such confidence in her. We’re overwhelmed by the work that they did with her and how easy they’ve made the process for us. “Now Jemima is becoming quite cheeky and loves to spend time with us. She is so happy, has wonderful manners, and is very clever and eager to learn. She loved her first visit to the beach, enjoys going in the car, and had a fabulous first Christmas. “She is an absolute joy and embraces le with enormous enthusiasm. She has every reason to hate everybody, but she is so happy and is game for everything!” Bella, who was adopted by a family from Scotland, has also settled into her new home. Her new owner said: “Bella is doing really well we feel very fortunate to have her!”To help the RSPCA rescue more animals in need, like Bella and Jemima, please visit www.rspca.org.uk give to donate. story: Family lose £, after terrying sewage flood left flat furniture floatingGraphic designer David Benqué, , and his partner Claire OBrien, , say they lost £, worth of belongings and have since forked out £, when a freak flood destroyed their south London flatGraphic designer David Benqué, , and his partner Claire OBrien, , have spent nearly £, replacing damaged items Image: David Benqué My LondonByCallum CuddefordAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsA family who said theyaposve lost £, after sewage flooded their home claim Thames Water have refused to compensate them. Graphic designer David Benqué, , and his partner Claire OaposBrien, , say they lost £, worth of belongings when a freak flood destroyed their south London flat. They claim they have since spent nearly £, replacing damaged items and relocating - bringing the total spent to £,. The couple says they are furious with Thames Water, who they claim gave them no compensation after a collapsed sewer caused the carnage in September .Thames Water refused legal liability because there were no previous issues with the sewer, therefore they claim they were not negligent, MyLondon reports.  Thames Water also reportedly asked the couple to sign a letter meaning they wonapost pay for aposun-restorableapos items. David and Claire say they refused to sign the letter and had to fork out £, to dispose of the wrecked belongings themselves. David said: I was alerted to the sound and the smell, something did not seem right. I saw a torrent of water. The pipe that exploded was under a bin so there was a bunch of rubbish floating.  I opened the door and saw the whole staircase was like a waterfall. I closed the door and for a couple of seconds, my brain said it would be fine. Then I knew it was not going to be okay so I woke my partner up. Once Claire was awake they grabbed the children, their teddies and put an iPad up high. David said he got his coat and laptop, but the computer later fell into the sludge.  David recalled: The water was coming through the door so we thought it was time to go out, then the door opened and let a torrent of sewage in. Our furniture started floating and then it got pretty intense.The fire brigade arrived as the water was filling the basement.David added: I was carrying my five-year-old, I saw the firefighters so I crawled so they could see us. They helped my partner who was carrying the three-year-old and she could not walk forward the pressure was so strong, so he was carried by a fireman.  The coupleaposs flat wasnapost the only one affected and other neighbours were rescued from their windows because the water pressure was so strong. By the next day, the extent of the damage could be seen and the costs started to mount up. Thames Water said the family was not eligible for the hardship fund. David said: We are lucky we have family and friends that are able to help us, but we are broke as hell now. There were lots of upsetting moments but when you walk into your flat and see a book your kidsapos like and itaposs covered in muck. You could see stuff that was familiar but itaposs all in the wrong place and everything is covered. Then we realised they were not going to give us any money at all. Textile designer Claire said: Now the time has passed it was actually a really traumatic event to be woken up to a torrent of water rushing into your home. The trauma of seeing how much water was in our flat, just filled up like a bath. Itaposs been really dficult just the devastation, the time and stress to get back on our feet and have nothing from Thames Water. We feel like criminals that do not matter when itaposs their pipe that exploded on our lives. A few hours earlier it could have been a very dferent story but it was still pretty terrying. The fact that it was sewage water, itaposs toxic. The kidsapos stuff is sentimental, they still talk about it all the time. It makes you think lots of people would not be able to get back on their feet. That really stuck with me, the utter devastation, everything gone within five minutes. Itaposs a terrible thing for your family to go through. Itaposs not our fault, or climate change, itaposs Thames Water. A Thames Water spokesperson told The Mirror: “We understand how distressing sewer flooding is and we sympathise with anyone affected. “In this case, the flooding was caused by a collapsed sewer which caused sewage to spill out into nearby properties. Our engineers were quickly on the scene and carried out repairs as a matter of urgency. Investigations show there were no previous issues with the sewer which would have contributed to the collapse, and as such Thames Water was not negligent and is not legally liable for the damage caused. “As with all sewer flooding, we offered to clean and sanitise affected properties, which includes removing belongings which are too damaged to be ed to the property. In order to do this, we ask our customers to sign a document acknowledging that we won’t be reimbursing them for the items removed. “We encourage anyone affected by the devastating impact of sewer flooding to make a claim through their home insurance provider.” Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Thames Water PLCiPadClimate changeHouse insuranceFloods" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates from our environment editor on green issues and actions you can takeInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. story: Lesser-known Highway Code rule means motorists parking wrong way could face £, fineA lesser-known Highway Code rule means drivers can be slapped with a hefty fine for parking the wrong way. WhatCar reports that drivers are banned from parking their cars against the flow of traffic as the reflectors would not be picked up by oncoming vehiclesParking your car the wrong way at night could incur a hefty fine Image: Getty ImagesByAriane Sohrabi-ShirazSEO EditorLeonie Chao-Fong:,  Jan Updated:,  Mar |commentsA little known Highway Code rule could see motorists slapped with a fine between £, and £, -they park against the flow of traffic at night time. WhatCar, an automobile magazine, reports that drivers are actually banned from parking their cars against the direction of traffic unless there’s a marked out parking space. Even the most disciplined driver could be forgiven for not knowing this unusual fact. The Highway Code lists under Rule  that a car must not be parked at the side of the road facing against the direction of traffic unless in a recognised parking space”. If it is, then you could be breaking the law.This is because parking facing the traffic on unlit roads can be extremely dangerous, according to car scrapping comparison site, scrapcarcomparison. This means it could be harder for other motorists to detect what you are doing, potentially leading to crashes.  Cars parked in the same direction of traffic will have the rear reflectors illuminated. A spokesman said: Motors parked the correct way would be visible and illuminated by headlights bouncing off the rear reflectors. We’ve dealt with cars that have been written-off due to a passing car crashing into them as they have partly stuck out from a parking space. For most vehicles, the offence could cost around £,, whereas for eight-seaters, this jumps to £,. However, drivers donapost need to worry about this during the day, but as it gets darker it could become an issue. Another sloppy parking habit has seen motorists fined for leaning slightly over the edge of a parking bay - an expensive start to the year and unwelcome surprise after Christmas. Leaving your car stationary in a parking bay should be a fairly straightforward process - but you can actually get finedyou donapost stick to the rules.As the Mirror reported last year, a driver left the side of his car protruding slightly over the bay line in Birmingham City Centre, encroaching on the space next door. He was charged £ for doing so. The fine - which would be reduced to £paid within  days - was issued by private firm Premier Parking Enforcement LTD who are contracted by building management company Remus. title: how britains most wanted woman
story: Exclusive: How Britains most wanted woman evaded justice for nine years before being caughtSarah Panitzke vanished during her London trial for laundering £billion in a mobile phone VAT fraud. She then wore a wig to flee the Spanish villa where she had been under surveillance in Sarah Panitzke was caught after being on the run for nine years Image: PAByTom PettorCrime Editor:,  Mar  A British crook who fled police waiting to arrest her by disguising herself in a wig has finally been held after nine years on the run.Sarah Panitzke, , vanished during her  London trial for laundering £billion in a mobile phone VAT fraud.Two years later, she sneaked away from a Spanish bolthole as officers closed in. Panitzke was caught last Sunday as she walked her dogs in Santa Barbara, between ­Barcelona and Valencia. The head of the elite ­Fugitive Task Force squad which nabbed her told yesterday of her disguise and dramatic escape in . He said: “It was like ­something out of a film.  “She appeared by her door to smoke and one officer passed by to get a closer look. “She saw him and changed her clothes, donned a wig and a small rucksack before heading for the mountains beside the house a few moments later. “It’s very rare to find people as prepared as she was.” He revealed after her arrest Panitzke, who had been living under the alias Maria ­Antonietta, claimed she felt she had already done her time, having lived in isolation for so many years. The officer added: “She also complained she was only able to buy a cheap gin for her gin and tonics as her money started to run out.” Panitzke, of Fulford, North Yorks, was sentenced to eight years in her absence for the fraud. She is in prison near Madrid, fighting extradition. story: Huge delays and massive queues at Dublin and Manchester airports prompt passenger furyOne passenger at Manchester Airport said her flight to Gran Canaria with TUI left more than two hours late due to delays getting the luggage onto the planeHuge airport delays as massive queues at Dublin and Manchester airports Image: Clare OHanlon TwitterByAshlie BlakeyLaura SharmanNews Reporter:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsFuming passengers have been hit by a second wave of delays at Manchester Airport where firefighters are helping to tackle mammoth queues. Fire crew have been asked to work on the baggage belts and travellers complained of massive lines at security that took hours to get through, it has been claimed.Queues at check-in desks were described as beyond a joke causing some people to miss their flights and leaving others in tears on Monday. It marked the second day of delays at the international hub amid staff shortages which saw some passengers stuck on the runway for two-and-a-half hours.One airport worker told the Manchester Evening News : “It’s been so bad that they have been asking firefighters, engineers and parking staff to offload the bags onto the conveyors in the arrivals hall. “I think the summer is going to be horrendous, at this rate we just won’t have the staff, and morale is already low. I just hope that we get the staff we need in time and get back to normal. One woman said her flight to Gran Canaria with TUI departed more than two hours late due to delays getting the baggage on the plane. Kathleen Moorland said she was still sitting on the plane on the runway at .pm, when it was meant to be departing at .am.She added that there were delays getting through queues at the airport, despite arriving more than three hours before her flight. Kathleen said: TUI and Manchester Airport, a total farce and joke. All you want is an easy start to your holiday - not the total chaos that there is. Julia Teale tweeted: @manairport. You really need to sort your staffing issues. Just witnessed people missing flights who have been here three hours but security was so disorganised it’s taking hours to get through. If it’s like this in March what will it be like in high season. Not enough staff.  Martijn van der Voort also tweeted: When will @manairport @AndyBurnhamGM @ManCityCouncil grasp that the airport is one of the worst in the world  From rude security staff to long queues to poor infrastructure and parking. Truly terrible airport and I have been to many across the globe. On Sunday, passengers were also faced with ridiculous two-hour queues amid a workforce shortage, sparking fears of more chaos for passengers in the busy summer ahead. It is estimated that more than , redundancies were made at Manchester Airport as the aviation sector was savaged by the pandemic. This included around  workers employed directly by the hub and more than , by outside employers like baggage handling agents and airlines.Now travel restrictions are lting, passenger numbers are on the rise and plans to reopen Terminal  are also in the pipeline. But questions have been raised as to whether the workforce can meet demand in what Manchester Airport bosses have described as an extremely challenging labour market. Airport bosses apologised over long delays and horrendous queues at passport control on Friday. A spokesperson for Manchester Airport said queues on both days were due to a greater number of passengers than expected. Passengers have been urged to get to the airport at least three hours before their scheduled flight time. A spokesperson for Swissport, which handles baggage for TUI, said: “We would like to apologise to those passengers who experienced baggage delays at Manchester Airport following an aircraft change which impacted our resource allocation. We have worked with our airport partners to remedy the delays and normal service has resumed. Thehas contacted Manchester Airport for further comment. title: mothers day exact day changes
story: When is Mothers Day   Date and why the date changes every yearAs International Womens Day is celebrated across the globe through events and online campaigns, some people are being reminded that Mothers Day is also not very far away tooInternational Womens Day has reminded a few people of Mothers Day, which is coming round again soon Image: Getty Images iStockphotoByBenjamin LynchTrends Writer:,  Mar |comments With International Womenaposs Day being celebrated across the world, people are being reminded that Motheraposs Day is also looming.Believe it or not, some people seem to have the two confused as people are reminded of the impact of womenaposs achievements through the centuries and how there is still a way to go to achieving gender equality. With the focus of the day on this, it is no wonder that some people have been reminded that Mothering Sunday is only around the corner, as people looking forward to showing their appreciation for their mum and everything she has done for them So when is Motheraposs Day  When is Motheraposs Day   Motheraposs Day this year falls on Sunday, March . The term aposMotheraposs Dayapos technically means the day dedicated to the celebration of mums everywhere, whereas Mothering Sunday tended to refer to a Christian tradition that began in the th century where people would visit either the church they grew up in or were baptised.  The dates for the next few years are as follows: - March   - March   - March   - March Why does the Motheraposs Day date change   The celebration falls on the fourth Sunday in Lent and the date changes depending on Easter and the Christian calendar. Easter and Lent changes every year depending on the cycle of the moon and means that Easter Sunday can occur on any Sunday between March  and April  Motheraposs Day shouldnapost be confused with the day in the US, which falls in May and has ious sources that helped to set it up. Why do we celebrate Motheraposs Day   There are ious reasons we celebrate Motheraposs Day, but it is now seen as a chance to be grateful to our mum for everything they have done for us over the years Until recently it was more commonly known as aposMothering Sundayapos. There were ancient Greek festivals that celebrated motherhood as well in honour of their god Rhea and festivals were also held by the Romans, so the tradition is nothing new. In Europe and the UK, a special service would see people ing to their aposmother churchapos during Lent. Like with other Christian holidays, such as Christmas and Easter, the day has become more of a secular tradition and widely commercialised.  In the US, abolitionist and suffragette Julia Ward Howe set up Mothers’ Friendship Day in the wake of the American Civil War in  to promote reconciliation with the mothers of Union and Confederate troops. In fact, Anna Jarvis, who pushed for the idea for Motheraposs Day to be celebrated in the US as part of the national calendar, eventually criticised the commercialisation of the day and lobbied to have it removed. Jarvis was the daughter of Ann Reeves Jarvis, who had set up work clubs for mums to come together. Anna had originally campaigned to have it as part of the national calendar and President Woodrow Wilson officially added it in . title: new variant proof cambridge university
story: New iant proof Cambridge University Covid jab receives backing worth millionsThe new "iant proof" coronavirus vaccine by Cambridge University has received global backing worth up to £million with PM Boris Johnson commending the projectMedical staff and volunteers prepare shots of the Moderna vaccine at an NHS Covid- vaccination centre Image: Getty ImagesByMartin BagotHealth and Science editor:,  Mar |commentsA new “iant proof” coronavirus vaccine by Cambridge University has received global backing worth millions of pounds.Prime Minister Boris Johnson hailed the project to develop the “NextGen” jab against known and future iants.He spoke via video link at the opening of a conference of the Coalition for Epidemic Preparedness Innovationsin London which is partnering with the university to make the jab. CEPI will invest up to £million towards a version of mRNA technology already used in Moderna and Pfizer jabs that could be quickly modied to target new pathogens. Mr Johnson said: “The UK is proud to have committed to a quarter of a billion pounds to support CEPI at the start of the pandemic, because it was precisely the partnership between CEPI, government, industry and academia which helped our vaccines to triumph over the virus.  “And now, we must come together to support CEPI’s global plan for the next generation of vaccine technologies, such as the new iant-proof vaccine being developed at Cambridge University to help protect us against the next Covid iant, or indeed, against the next pandemic.” DIOSynVax, a university spin-off company, is working with the structure of proteins, computational biology and on boosting the immune system to work out how vaccines can be used to their best effect. If the plan works, experts believe that vaccines could rapidly be developed against “Disease X” - unknown pathogens that have yet to emerge but which could cause pandemics.Dr Richard Hatchett, chief executive of CEPI, said: “The UK Government and the country’s world-leading scientic institutions have been pivotal to the global response to Covid-. “From the development of the CEPI-supported Oxford AstraZeneca vaccine - which is used in more countries than any other - to the ground-breaking Recovery trial to evaluate le-saving treatments like dexamethasone, British science has played a leading role in protecting the world from Covid-. “I am excited to further strengthen CEPI’s strong ties to British science through this partnership with DIOSynVax.” Professor Jonathan Heeney, chief executive of DIOSynVax, said: “Our approach is to be ahead of the next pandemic. “To deliver custom-designed, immune selected vaccine antigens - which is ideal to prevent diseases caused by complex viruses such as the large and erse family of coronaviruses. “If successful, it will result in a safe, affordable NextGen vaccine for widespread use.” England’s chief medical officer, Professor Sir Chris Whitty, told the CEPI conference the world had had many “near misses” with pandemics, and preparation for the next one was key. title: squid named joe biden weird
story: Squid named Joe Biden is weird prehistoric primitive vampire with  armsSyllipsimopodi bideni was armed with two more limbs than its descendants today and roamed the oceans  million years ago - he was named after US President Joe Biden to mark the moment of optimism of his inaugurationA host of strange animals have been named after Joe Bidens predecessors - including the tiny moth Neopalpa donaldtrumpi Image: Getty ImagesByMark WaghornRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Mar |comments A weird prehistoric squid with ten arms has been named after US President Joe Biden.The creature is the oldest ancestor of cephalopods - which also include octopae. Syllipsimopodi bideni was armed with two more limbs than its descendants today. It roamed the oceans  million years ago. Additional appendages would have made it a more efficient predator, say the team at the American Museum of Natural History in New York.The species was unearthed at the Mississippian Bear Gulch in Montana - one of the best preserved fossil sites in the world.It was a primitive vampire squid. They do not suck or drink blood but have dark skin that connects the arms - resembling a cape. The discovery sheds fresh light on evolution - pushing back the age of the group by nearly  million years.What do you make of squid Joe Biden  Have your say in the comment section Lead author Dr Christopher Whalen said: This is the first and only known vampyropod to possess ten al appendages. The paper was submitted for publication in Nature Communications around the time of the  year-old US presidentaposs inauguration. Dr Whalen said: I wanted to somehow acknowledge the moment in a way that was more positive and forward-looking. I was encouraged by the plans President Biden put forward to counter anthropogenic climate change, and his general sentiment that politicians should listen to scientists. Vampyropods are the ancestors of vampire squid and octopae. Their origins are unclear. Modern descendants have eight arms and two big eyes - enabling them to survive in pitch black waters near the bottom of the ocean. Octopae and squid can reach  and  feet long respectively - and weigh half a ton.  S. bideni was less than five inches showing they started out small - before becoming very big. Its remains are exceptionally important. The soft-bodied nature of cephalopods mean they rarely fossilise. Co-author Professor Neil Landman said: Syllipsimopodi may have filled a niche more similar to modern squids, a mid-level aquatic predator. It is not inconceivable it might have used its sucker-laden arms to pry small ammonoids out of their shells or ventured more inshore to prey on brachiopods, bivalves or other shelled marine animals. S. bideni was dug up in the s and donated to the Royal Ontario Museum in Canada where it has resided ever since - without previously being described. After scanning the specimen Dr Whalen and Prof Landman realised it was a completely new genus - and the oldest cephalopod on record. It corroborates previous arguments that their common ancestor had ten arms.Dr Whalen said: The arm count is one of the defining characteristics separating the -armed squid and cuttlefish line from the eight armed octopus and vampire squid line. We have long understood that octopuses achieve the eight arm count through elimination of the two filaments of vampire squid, and that these filaments are vestigial arms. However, all previously reported fossil vampyropods preserving the appendages only have  arms. So this fossil is arguably the first confirmation of the idea that all cephalopods ancestrally possessed ten arms. Two of S. bideniaposs arms appear to have been elongated relative to the other eight. Its torpedo-shaped body is reminiscent of todayaposs squids. The genus name is Greek for aposprehensile footapos because it is the oldest known cephalopod to develop suckers. They allowed the arms - modications of the molluscan foot - to better grasp prey and other objects. Added Dr Whalen: The findings present a revised and more detailed analysis of vampyropod evolution than previously possible. Joe Biden was inaugurated on  January last year. He is the th president of the United States. A host of strange animals have been named after his predecessors - including the tiny moth Neopalpa donaldtrumpi. The insectaposs yellow-and-white crown bore a striking resemblance to Donald J. Trumpaposs distinctive cofure. Baracktrema obamai is a species of flatworm that is meant to honour Barack Obama. The parasitic wasp Heterospilus washingtoni is named after George Washington, a tiny shrew Heterospilus washingtoni hails Theodore Roosevelt - and there is the bluegrass darter Etheostoma jimmycarter. Others include the beaded darter Etheostoma clinton after Bill Clinton and the wasp Heterospilus reagani after Ronald Reagan. news uk-news woman-who-met-raf-airman-"CCTV shows the last confirmed sighting of Corrie McKeagueBySam RussellGraeme Murray:,  Mar |comments A young woman who met RAF airman Corrie McKeague on a night out has told an inquest he mentioned walking home from Bury St Edmunds to his base. Mr McKeague, of Dunfermline, Fe, was  when he vanished in the early hours of September   after a night out in the Suffolk town.The airman was stationed at RAF Honington, more than eight miles from Bury St Edmunds. No trace of him has been found since a last sighting on CCTV at .am entering a service area behind a Greggs store, and Suffolk Police believe he climbed into a bin which was then tipped into a waste lorry. Alicia Gallagher, giving evidence to an inquest in Ipswich by video link, said she first met Mr McKeague on a night out in Bury St Edmunds in December .She said she was with her sister at Flex nightclub and saw a number of people who were in smart dress formal wear, like tuxes. One of them was on his own, she said. We were just out dancing really and he stayed with us for a couple of hours until closing. She continued: He was actually just really friendly. He wasnapost flirty. He was just really sociable - it was like he was looking for people to chat to.  She said that when they left, at around .am, she was taking a taxi with her sister in a dferent direction from Mr McKeague. My sister was concerned he wasnapost going home with anyone, said Ms Gallagher. We offered him some money for a taxi - he did mention a base but he didnapost say which base it was. He said he walked... one time which my sister wasnapost happy with. In the end I think he just wandered off.She continued: He said he had done it before, which I remember as we talked about it in the taxi home and said aposthataposs so farapos. Itaposs something I remember from that night as I thought aposthataposs so far, I wouldnapost do thatapos, but then Iaposm not a young, fit male either. It was a striking point that he mentioned walking home, that he had done it before. She said she saw Mr McKeague a second time on September   in Wetherspoons in Bury St Edmunds. She said she was with a friend for a casual drink when Mr McKeague, who did not recognise her, pulled up a chair. Ms Gallagher said he was very friendly, very confident. She said when she recognised him she found a video of him with her sister on the previous night out, showed it to him, then sent her sister a Snapchat video of Mr McKeague saying hello. She said he left after a few minutes. Aaron Figge, who worked in the Spar shop at RAF Honington, said in a statement that Mr McKeague bought a bottle of vodka from the shop on Friday, September  . He said Mr McKeague was among his regular customers who he became friendly with, describing him as a very happy, chatty person who was always well-presented and seemed a nice guy. I was aware he lived on the base as he was a regular customer, he said.  He asked to see ious bottles of vodka and while choosing he chatted to me, said Mr Figge. He stated he had not had a good day at work - this was not usual for Corrie as he was usually so upbeat. He said he believed Mr McKeague bought a cl bottle of Spar vodka, the cheapest bottle in the store, for between £ and £, and also bought cigarettes, paying by card. We said bye to each other and he left the shop, he said. The inquest, due to last for up to four weeks, continues. story: Woman wins medal in male-dominated sport after being selected to represent GBFaye West has been selected to represent her country in the male-dominated sport of wheelchair rugby, and in a recent match in the European Championships she scored a silver medalFaye West is now competing in Team GBByJohn BettAudience WriterNino Robertson:,  Mar |commentsA woman has won a medal in a male-dominated sport after being selected to represent her country in an international competition.Faye West is just one of two women competing in wheelchair rugby in the European Championships, and now plays for Team GB alongside Paralympic Champion Kylie Grimes.They have now played in France and the -strong squad won a silver medal after being narrowly beaten by the home team, with a final score of -. Despite not winning her first tournament, Faye is excited to launch her career in one of the only full-contact disability sports - one that is also open to men and women competing on the same team. What do you about wheelchair rugby  Let us know in the comments....Speaking before the event, Faye, from Plymouth, Devon, said: It is a huge honour to be selected for GB, I am super excited to get stuck in and be part of an awesome squad. I can’t wait to start my rugby career at the Europeans - what a competition to have a debut! Faye, who plays for West Country Hawks, was the only female high-point player in the tournament, and last year Team GB claimed gold, grabbing the news headlines and making history. Ed Warner, chair of the team, said: Our success in Tokyo has deservedly brought more attention to this amazing sport and we are intent on using this increased awareness to further build our profile, introducing wheelchair rugby to more people, supporting the sport nationally at grassroots level and building our communities. title: kenyan hotel sas hero who
story: Kenyan hotel SAS hero who single handedly took on jihadis reveals his identitySAS hero Christian Craighead was the lone special-ops soldier who fought off a major terror attack at a Kenyan hotel in  - here he speaks publicly for the first time about that dayChristian Craighead on Evan Hafers podcastByChristopher BucktinUnited States Editor:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |comments The SAS hero who battled Kenyan hotel terrorists has spoken publicly for the first time, telling how being shot felt like banging your funny bone times by ,.The special forces veteran, known as Christian Craighead, revealed how his arm was once left hanging by the triceps after being hit by a bullet fired from a Dragunov sniper rle. Speaking on Evan Haferaposs Black Rle Coffee Podcast in the US, the decorated hero said: In the back of my mind Iaposm like aposIaposve been shot, thataposs coolapos, then thereaposs like aposI hope I donapost lose my armapos. Speaking with a hint of his Geordie accent, he went on: This is the strange thing. Now it hurt badly. When it goes through that bone. And I get it when people say when they get shot, they donapost feel it. I completely buy into thatit doesnapost go through a bone.  But once it goes through a bone and shatters it, it hurts. It was like banging your funny bone and times by ,. Thataposs what it felt like. But hereaposs the messed-up bit. Going back into junior para, being indoctrinated and things, there was a sense of satisfaction. It was like, aposoh, Iaposve just been shot, thataposs pretty coolapos. In the back of my mind, Iaposm like aposIaposve been shot, thataposs cool, then thereaposs like aposI hope I donapost lose my armapos. And my arm was hanging by the triceps but, having some medical knowledge. I could wriggle my fingers.And in my mind, again just thinking, thataposs not that bad because I can wriggle my fingers. In my mind, I was thinking, aposIaposm going to keep my armapos. He suffered a shattered humerus and now has a titanium rod implanted from his elbow to shoulder. Craighead added: I think most young soldiers, maybe, you kind of want to get shot because itaposs like a thing isnapost it, like aposoh Iaposve been shotapos. Itaposs a be careful what you wish for, isnapost it. And you kind of want it to happen, you want to be tested. And sometimes death is a price where you say aposdo you know what, I donapost mind dyingapos.  I think there are lots of people who havenapost seen combat who wouldaposve said aposI will sacrice my le to experience that combatapos. I think thataposs part of training, mindset, everything that comes to it. Craighead, who joined the army in  as a -year-old, was pictured in January  during the Nairobi hotel siege. He was in Kenya on a SAS mission to train local forces and was relaxing off-duty when Somali-based Al Shabaab militants attacked the Dusit D complex.He raced to the scene in his civvies, pulled on a camouflage flak jacket, then led a counter-attack armed with a Colt Canada C assault rle, Glock  pistol and combat kne. Wearing a balaclava and heavily armed, he almost single-handedly defeated jihadis, rescuing dozens. The -hour siege left  people dead, including British charity worker Luke Potter. It was only last year, Craighead, who won a Conspicuous Gallantry Cross, the UKaposs second-highest medal for his heroics, unmasked himself so he could publish an account of how he ended the terror attack. His move came after people kept impersonating him on social media and in pubs near the SASaposs Hereford base. Craigheadaposs decision to unmask himself sparked deep concern among senior or defence officials, worried he may reveal details of the missions he was involved in. Under strict rules, Special Forces troops must not discuss their operations publicly and seek to make money from revealing their details. The rules follow the furore over books by ex-troopers Chris Ryan and Andy McNab, which raised the SASapos public profile and led to concerns over Special Forces troops leaking sensitive information which could compromise future operations. Craigheadaposs book on the siege called One Man In: The Explosive Firsthand Account of the Lone Special-Ops Soldier Who Fought Off a Major Terrorist Attack in Kenyaapos, is expected to be published in June next year.Discussing the MOD rules and confidentiality issues, he said: Iaposm working with the Ministry of Defence as we speak to do it properly, to release this book, so thereaposs no sense of information or anything.So thataposs as far as Iaposm willing to talk about my le in the nd Special Air Service Regiment. I should add that the book is just about that one day, so for anyone on the edge of their seats, it doesnapost talk about anything I did while serving in the unit. It just talks about one thing I did that we all know I did. The Newcastle-born hero currently spends much of his time in the States as he is engaged to Donald Trumpaposs chief White House photographer Shealah Craighead. title: clearest ever spooky figure caught
story: Clearest ever spooky figure caught on camera by ghost hunters at haunted jailLinzi and Lee Steer, from Rotherham, who run Project reveal - Ghosts of Britain say their latest capture is the clearest image they have taken in their decades of ghost hunting experienceNumerous visitors have reported spooky phenomena and paranormal activity in the stone cells and passageways of Inveraray JailImage: Getty ImagesByAmber OConnorJoe Smith:,  Mar |commentsGhosts hunters say they have caught their clearest-ever evidence of spooky activity on camera during a recent trip to a haunted site. Linzi and Lee Steer, who run Project reveal - Ghosts of Britain say their latest capture is the clearest image they have taken in their decades of ghost hunting experience. The couple from Rotherham, who have over  years of paranormal research experience between them, have snapped what many of their fans believe is an apparition in the form of a ghostly face.The experienced investigators live stream all their hunts and they were alerted to the spooky visage when fans spotted it on a Facebook clip,Yorkshire Live reports. I just canapost get over it. It is so clear and distinctive, said Linzi. The pair spotted the photo after a visit to Inveraray Jail.The couple, who go on daily ghost hunts, live-stream all of their investigations on Facebook and ask viewers to screenshot any unusual sightings. But when they looked back at the photos from their trip to the Scottish jail and courtroom, they were left shocked. A figure can be seen behind a waxwork model in multiple screenshots, according to Linzi. While she said she could not see the figure while she was filming, she has been left unable to explain what her viewers saw. Linzi said: We try to debunk everything, but thereaposs no dummy there in that particular area.  She added: It is definitely not human. If it was one of us you could tell with the colouring, but it looked very transparent. The apparent figure wasnapost the only spooky part of their trip either. Husband Lee revealed he had an unnerving experience when looking around the siteaposs jail blocks. I walked into one of them and I felt a tickling sensation on my throat, and it started to get more intense to the point where I had to run outside, he said. Although they didnapost know it at the time, the couple were later told by staff that many people have reported feeling a choking sensation in the same spot. Lee added: That is the first time Iaposve ever felt that kind of thing. Iaposm actually sceptical when it comes to ghosts.You can see the screenshots for yourself and see more of the investigatorsapos work here. news weird-news inside-eerie-nuclear-bunker-cold-"Real footage of a Cold War nuclear bunkerByZahna EklundAudience writerRia Newman:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |comments A brave explorer has uncovered a secret network of nuclear bunkers hidden in the Welsh countryside that were used during the Cold War, and have more recently become set pieces for an episode of Doctor Who. Jay Curtis, , stumbled upon the interesting find late last year when he noticed the network tucked away in the countryside in Brackla, Bridgend.And when the explorer, from Wales, investigated the area he found nuclear blast doors, as well as an air filtration system, generator and water and diesel storage. The bunkers also housed eight secret magazine tunnels that were built to protect the high explosives held within the Brackla Munitions Factory, where , people worked during the Second World War. Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. Jay explored the area and shared the find on his YouTube channel, Jay Curtis Explores, where he said: “Now this place might look like any ordinary industrial estate, but with the imminent Second World War upon Britain this place became one of the most secretive places in South Wales – and there’s plenty of other hidden history left overyou know where to look. “Inside the bunker is a maze of rooms for personnel, beds, a canteen, recreation, offices, communication centres – you name it. This bunker remains locked and forgotten in the hillside.”The Royal Ordnance Factory stopped production of the explosives in  and the site was left abandoned until the s, when the Ministry of Defenceturned part of the site into a nuclear command bunker for South Wales.While the bunker appears totally abandoned and reclaimed by nature, with leaves and plants growing up around it, Jay revealed it still has its own power supply.  Jay added: “You can tell by the well-maintained road and new locks that this place is very much still in use.” It is currently not clear who is using the site, but it has previously been used as a filming location for Doctor Who and Torchwood, where the crew was allowed access to film episodes featuring the iconic Cybermen villains. According to Jay, everything inside the locked bunkers remains “in full working order”. Standing outside the entrance, Jay explained: “That bizarre-looking square building behind me was in fact originally a magazine tunnel entrance, but this new entrance was added with the imminent threat of a nuclear attack – hence the air filtration system, the generator inside, the water and the diesel storage, and a series of nuclear blast doors.”  The magazine tunnels are also still intact and “scattered across the landscape”. Jay said: “Many have been filled in but two or three entrances above ground give an idea of what a secretive past this hillside once had. It’s in these dark magazine tunnels that thousands upon thousands of tonnes of explosives would be piled high to the ceiling, hidden away from the enemy and the threat from above.” And further down the hillside, Jay found the remains of more tunnels, with the main access and ventilation shafts now filled in.  Speaking after sharing his video, he said: “It was a complete surprise to find this as I went looking for evidence of the former munitions factory tunnels and did not expect to stumble across the bunkers in the woods. The feeling below ground was very eerie. You could hear nothing from le above ground. “The damp environment within the bunker offered little resemblance to its signicant past – just a chemical toilet, cupboard, some BT junction box and wiring, and the remains of the water pump could be found inside.”Do you have a story to sell  Get in touch with us at yourmirror@trinitymirror .Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Viralproperty news" data-immediate"data-immediate" to FREE email alerts from our Property Market newsletterSubscribeInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news weird-news i-tested-five-dferent-brands-"Spilling the tea on what makes the best cuppa ByJulia BanimAudience Writer:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |comments Like many people, I drink far too much tea, but rarely stop to consider the dference a decent tea bag can make.After all, Iaposve long been more worried about the atrocities some well-meaning pals can commit with a carton of milk, leaving me battling to taste the leaves through the dairy. Plus, rarely in le do we actually try one type of tea bag directly after the other, unless youaposre at some sort of fancy tea tasting experience, and so itaposs sometimes dficult to discern which brand actually comes out on top. With this in mind, I decided to pit five iconic tea brands against each other, in what I promise is far more than just a very cheeky excuse to nab a particularly y tea break at work.I sampled bags from Tetleyaposs, Yorkshire Tea, PG Tips, Aldiaposs Diplomat Gold Blend and Twinings, ranking each one in terms of all-important factors such as flavour, moreish-ness and, of course, how well they take a good biscuit dunking.Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. PG Tips -  ******* £. from the Co-op for  bags of teaFirst things first, I went for a slug of PG Tips fas this has become, for whatever reason, my tried and trusted bag of choice in recent years, a brand which I chuck in the basket without really thinking too much about it.However, this just goes to show that you should branch out every now and then when it comes to your store cupboard staples, with this household name not quite hitting the mark when compared to its fellow tea break giants. PG Tips doesn’t quite pack the same powerful punch as other teas, and I noticed a slightly thin, watery taste when compared with more flavourful options. Despite not making too much of an impact on me, this is still an enjoyable drink, with no lingering unpleasant aftertaste. I also found that the more subtle notes made it ideal for biscuit dipping.Twinings - .  ********   £. Tesco for pack of Being at the pricier end of the spectrum, I would usually only plump for TwiningsI spied it on offer somewhere. Given that it does feel rather more suited to afternoon scones with the Queen than a rushed, microwaved job ahead of mid-week Zoom calls, it doesnapost exactly feel in sync with my day-to-day le.However, that said, this is a very good quality tea, and one that I donapost mind buying every now and then as a special treat. Of course, I had to sip it from my fanciest Jane Austen Museum china cup, like the lady I am and was pleased as ever by the light flavours and comforting toastiness. One of the more distinctive teas on the market, Twinings doesnapost have the same bitterness that spoils so many other products. But it narrowly misses out on the top spot given that the perfumed notes may get a little cloying after a few brew rounds. It felt wrong to submerge a biscuit in this one, but I had a good go anyway.Tetleys - .  ******   £. for  tea bags at Tesco Iaposve never personally been a Tetleyaposs drinker, and canapost say that Iaposve ever bought a bag myself as an adult. However, I have some vague memories of collecting the little figurine men as a kid, so the bag did infuse a bit of nostalgia.Admittedly, I was a little disappointed after going in for a gulp, and have to say that Iaposm somewhat surprised that this brand is as popular as it is, being the leading tea brand in UK convenience and independent grocery stores as of , according to Statistica. To be perfectly honest, I found Tetleyaposs to have quite a bitter, earthy taste which may well take a little getting used to for those used to smoother beverages. There was also quite a gravelly, dentistaposs waiting room-esque aftertaste that I would have expected from a lesser-known, cheaper label. I didnapost bother to dunk.Aldiaposs Diplomat Gold Blend -   ******** p for a pack of  at AldiI love Aldi and do the majority of my recipe shopping there, but this is the first time Iaposve gone for a bag of Aldiaposs own tea.Although I do like to be adventurous with my food, Iaposm a stickler for habit when it comes to tea and coffee brands, and - I must say - Iaposve learned a lesson on this front.I opted for a pack of Aldiaposs Diplomat Gold Blend and was immediately impressed by the pretty scenic packaging, which looks a far cry from what youaposd typically imagine a discount box of tea to look like. However, the most pleasant surprise of all was the quality taste, with mellow, rounded mouthfuls making for a very satisfying - and biscuit-worthy - post-sht pick-me-up. Being by far the best bang for your buck, this makes for a thrty swap likely to please even the pickiest of tea drinkers.  Yorkshire Tea -   ********** £. at the Co-op for  tea bagsAs Iaposve said, Iaposve mostly drunk PG Tips in recent times, but Iaposve previously been a Yorkshire Tea drinker through and through. This taste test made me wonder why Iaposd ever bothered to swap. Classic, hearty, and above all reassuring, Yorkshire Tea is a hardy brew built to weather the ious storms in le, and I knew it wouldnapost disappoint.Strong, yet moreish, flavourful but not overwhelming, this is the tea Iaposd opt for in a desert island scenario, knowing that it comforts me in my loneliest moments. In all honesty, the only reason Iaposm not giving this king of teas a solid ten out of ten is that Iaposm sure thereaposs some independent tea shop in some country village somewhere that might have just pipped it to the post. However,there is, Iaposm yet to find it. After some consideration, there can be no worthier winner than Yorkshire Tea, quite rightly voted as the UKaposs favourite brand last year in a poll by Tea and Coffee .The ever-elegant Twinings was my second runner-up, with Aldiaposs Diplomat Gold Blend coming in a very respectable third. My old go-to PG Tips didnapost quite compare, ranking fourth in the list, while Tetleys was my least favourite of the bunch.Do you have a food or drink-related story to tell  We pay for stories. story: International Womens Day :  things remarkable women have invented through historyAs the world celebrates this years International Womens Day, we take a look back at some of the most important and revolutionary inventions by women throughout historyInternational Womens Day is recognising the achievements of women around the world Image: AFP via Getty ImagesByBenjamin LynchTrends Writer:,  Mar |commentsInternational Womenaposs Day is upon us once again with the celebration of female achievement taking place around the world. The United Nations has formally acknowledged the day since  as a recognition of the struggle for womenaposs rights.The UN said: The year  is pivotal for achieving gender equality in the context of climate change, and environmental and disaster risk reduction, which are some of the greatest global challenges of the twenty-first century. Without gender equality today, a sustainable future, and an equal future, remains beyond our reach. It estimates that % of the . billion people living in conditions of poverty are women. Over the years, feminist movements have drawn attention to the need to redress the balance both within the workplace, socially, and in terms of how we think about the recognition of womenaposs contribution to the furthering of our society. Radical developments in engineering, science and general appliances have dramatically changed the face of the world we live in, but many would argue they are not as well recognised as they should be. Often, some of the best inventions go unnoticed, despite their use in our everyday lives. Who invented Kevlar   Kevlar was invented by Stephanie L. Kwolek, a Delware-based chemist. The material is used in bulletproof vests and other protective equipment, with its main features being that it is both light and strong.  It has saved countless lives over the years and is familiar to war reporters and soldiers. Kowelek patented the process of making Kevlar in . Who was Bessie Blount Grfin   The brilliant Bessie Blount Grfin was an American physical therapist known for working with soldiers during the first world war and inventing the feeding tube. Many soldiers became amputees due to the fighting and Blount noticed that much of the equipment was poor or inadequate. In her therapies, she taught amputees alternative ways of using their limbs, including people who lost their arms learning to use their mouths to write and their feet for general tasks.  Her invention of the feeding tube stands out the most, however, and meant that a tube inserted into the patientaposs mouth allowed them to eat independently and comfortably. Her aposportable receptacle support” was patented in  and the rights were bought by the French government one year later.After this, Blount went on to invent a disposable cardboard vomit basin, still standard in Belgian hospitals today according to Black Past.The History website argues she may well have been the first black woman to train at Scotland Yard’s Document Division, after moving into a career in forensics. Who was Ada Lovelace and what did she invent   The first computer algorithm is credited to pioneer mathematician Ada Lovelace. The daughter of poet Lord Byron, Ada built on the work by Italian mathematician Luigi Menabrea to formulate a code so elaborate and with such great depth that she is referred to as “the first computer programmer”.  Mathematician Anna Sfert from the Max Planck Institute for Mathematics said: If Ada had not written the first computer programme, someone  would have done it. The signicance of her work lies in the fact that she was the first to do so - a century before the invention of the computer. One-handed syringe  Letitia Mumford Greer patented the use of a one-handed syringe. Before this, a two-handed syringe was widely used by physicians.As the world continued to fight the coronavirus pandemic with a syringe or two, her invention was ahead of its time. The syringe did not initially become widely used when it was invented, as most drugs could not be injected, but the inventionaposs relevance grew and grew.Who invented the retractable dog leash  For people who have not had to follow their dog into the bushes to be greeted with all manner of unwanted substances, they can thank inventor Mary A. Delaney. In her own words, the intention was to stop our four-legged friends from running on the wrong side of lamp posts or pedestrians, thus causing much annoyance to the owner. Who invented the windscreen wiper   Crazy as it may seem, Mary Andersonaposs invention of windscreen wipers was not always standard on cars. She notice in a visit to New York City in  that passengers would get cold every time the driver opened the door to slip the window down, so set about inventing a new way of clearing the windscreen from inside the car.  Mary never profited from the invention, originally dismissed by car companies. What is stem cell isolation   Ann Tsukamoto was part of the team that found the first method of isolating blood-forming stem cells in . There is a huge amount of medical research into stem cells and they have been used in therapies for well over  years. Found in the bone marrow, stem cells are vital to cancer research. The University of Nebraska said: Research on stem cells continues to advance knowledge about how an organism develops from a single cell and how healthy cells replace damaged cells in adult organisms. story: Little girl with beautul voice made the world weep for children of UkraineThere has never been a more powerful version of Let It Go, Polly Hudson says of the footage from an underground bunker, reminding us how lives have been turned upside down for millions of innocentsAmelia singing in the bunker Image: PAopinionByPolly Hudson:,  Mar |commentsIt’s the chaos surrounding her that you notice first. The ­desperate families squeezed in, standing, sitting, lying wherever they can, next to their precariously piled ­belongings, packed into the dank underground space they now call home. There’s an air of restlessness, a palpable sense of tension and anxiety. How could there not be And then, completely unexpectedly, something magical happens. Little Amelia – age unknown, but probably, what, seven or eight  – stands up on a chair. She’s wearing a sparkly jumper with stars on it, from HM a few years ago – my friend’s daughter has the same one and still loves it too. Hands clenched together shyly, unbrushed hair pulled back into a ponytail, Amelia plucks up all her courage, opens her mouth and starts to sing Let It Go, from Frozen. And like a spell cast in the movie her song comes from, the Kyiv shelter falls silent. Everyone turns and gives this small blonde scrap of a girl their mesmerised full attention. No one moves. Babies stop crying. This captive audience cannot take their eyes off her, as they listen to her sweet, steady voice, a chink of shining light in the unimaginable ­darkness of Ukraine.She has given these people the gt of focusing on something other than the living nightmare they’re enduring, albeit briefly, and there isn’t a dry eye in the room. Or from any of the millions around the globe who have since watched the video on social media.Despite probably never having heard Ukrainian before, the song is in the universal language of Disney, kids from any country in the world watching it could name that tune in three. In the caption, the woman who posted it explains that Amelia told her she wanted to be “a singer on a grand stage” – an ambition now fulfilled, just not in a way anyone would want. Their poor parents can, at least, try to fight back, but the children of Ukraine are utterly defenceless in this war. Putin is torturing and traumatising these pure, faultless human beings, turning them into orphans. Murdering  of them.  Amelia and the other kids in that shelter, and similar ones across the country. Danya and Mpak, the boys trapped in Calais, denied entry by our callous government because they don’t have the right paperwork. The -year-old who braved a -mile journey to safety alone. Heroic President Volodymyr Zelensky’ s own children – Aleksandra, , and Kiril, age nine – who have targets on their backs. Polina, the girl with the pink hair, and her brother Semyon, both dead. story: Looter tied up and humiliated for trying to steal during Russian attack on KyivCivilians still living in Ukrainian cities are carrying out their own punishments on those caught looting as supplies run low with the Russian army encircling themThe man was found tied to a lamppost in Kyiv Image: dia images via Getty ImagesByAntony ThrowerNews Reporter:,  Mar |commentsA man caught looting in homes abandoned by people terried of the Russian war machine stands strapped to a lampost with his trousers down as punishment.The criminal, who seems to be a young man, was pictured standing outside near a petrol station in Ukraine ’s capital Kyiv unable to move after being caught by locals.Wearing a blue hoodie, his trousers have been pulled down to his knees as local people made an example of him. A police car stands nearby but it is unclearthe officers have arrived to save him from his humiliating predicament, or enforce the punishment. Other reports of looters being made examples of by people refusing to allow the situation in the capital to unravel have also emerged from the scenes of destruction.Follow all todayaposs latest updates on the conflict with our live blog Several videos have been shared on social media channels of people taped to lamposts in the under siege country with their trousers down. Some include footage of people being whipped on their bare bottoms. One user said: “Another video of punishing marauders in Ukraine! “My country isnapost for looters.” And in Odesa a sign posted in a market read: “Dear customers, I’m a volunteer that’s why no seller here. Just self service. Take it for freeyou have no money. Slava Ukraine. Slava Odessa. “P.S.you catch a looter - shoot him.” Reports have also been shared of people being stripped naked and beaten in the snow, although it has not been confirmed by authorities. Local media in Ukraine have shared videos of Russian soldiers looting grocery shops and banks amid claims they are running low on rations.Meanwhile a woman named Elana was previously praised as a local hero when she destroyed a drone reportedly used for looking for empty flats to target by looters with a jar of tomatoes. She told Liga Net that she was sitting on the balcony of her flat in Kyiv smoking when the drone suddenly appeared. In a bid to halt the device, she threw a jar of canned tomatoes and plums stored under her chair. Her shot knocked it out of the air and she and her husband collected the remnants of the drone into a number of bins, in case the device could be tracked. They also cleared up glass fragments so their neighbouraposs dogs wouldnapost risk suffering from cuts on their paws. She told the paper she thinks the device was operated by looters looking for empty flats to enter and steal from.Elena added that she decided instantly that she wouldnapost be leaving Kyiv after Russia invaded the country, and had no regrets about staying to fight.Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON SoldiersRussia Ukraine war" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: mum gives birth two babies
story: Mum gives birth to two babies in one year as each grow in her two dferent uterusesAfter thinking she was infertile due to a uterine condition, Caroline Wortman discovered she was nearly ten weeks pregnant with her second child, just six months after the birth of her first daughter, due to having two uterusesCaroline Wortman with husband Nate, Josie and baby Brooks.BySamantha Mordi:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |comments A mum who was told she was infertile gave birth to two babies in one year - as they each grew in her two dferent uteruses. Caroline Wortman, , discovered she was nearly ten weeks pregnant with her second child, Brooks, just six months after the birth of her first daughter, one-year-old Josie.This came after she was told that she may be infertile after being diagnosed with uterine didelphys, meaning she was born with two reproductive systems. Caroline said: Having children was always something I knew I wanted, but I just tried to stay positive and not dwell too much on it. Infertile was the story that I told myself for ten years. But after seven months of trying, Caroline became pregnant with Josie, and found out she was pregnant again just six months after her birth. Have you got an incredible story to tell  Email webnews@mirrorHer first ultrasound told her that her son was growing in the other uterus. Josie was in the right, Brooks was in the left said Caroline, from Woodstock, Georgia. For women with my specic diagnosis I just hope that this is one story that they can turn to and say aposlook, this girl was told no and she had two healthy babies in one yearapos, she said. Uterine Didelphys is caused because when a female foetus is growing, the uterus starts out as two small tubes called Mllerian ducts. These will eventually fuse together to form the reproductive system in a process called embryogenesis.  Women with uterine didelphys do not undergo full embryogenesis, and can be born with two full reproductive systems. Caroline was  when she had her first appointment with the gynaecologist who, after completing the exam, told her that she had two cervixes. She said: I honestly shrugged it off because I didnapost really realize what the implications could be. I did ask the doctor what having two cervixes meant and remember her telling me that I may be infertile andI did become pregnant, it would likely be complicated and high risk. I think this took years and meeting my husband to really sink in, but it was always in the back of my mind.  A couple of months later she went for an internal ultrasound where it was confirmed that she had two complete uteruses, and was diagnosed with uterine didelphys. She was also told that it may be dficult for her to get pregnant in the future. Caroline, who works for a law firm, said: I always knew I wanted to be a mum, I just wasnapost sure that I would be able to without adoption, surrogacy or some other intervention. As she grew up, her diagnosis did not affect her le, but things changed when she met her now-husband Nate Daniel Wortman, , when she was . The couple were married in September  and very quickly started trying for a family.  She said: I didnapost know how long it may take,at all. I was worried but you always hear worrying makes getting pregnant harder, so we just tried to be happy and relaxed as newlyweds about the whole thing.She found out she was pregnant in April .Her uterus that was not carrying her baby was simply pushed aside as it grew, and little Josie Magnolia Wortman was born on January  at a healthy six pounds.The family-of-three spent a happy six months as just that, before Caroline started feeling nauseous while out at lunch with her parents the following June.We were giggly with excitement but also still terried. The visual communications graduate said. The couple had not been trying for a second baby, but at her next appointment Caroline discovered she was already almost ten weeks along - and the baby was growing in her other uterus. She said: The baby was small enough each time to see the other uterus and confirm which side the baby was in - Josie was in the right, Brooks was in the left. Brooks Daniel Hayes Wortman was born on Boxing Day  weighing just lbs oz, and remained in the NICU for nine days.  She shared her unique pregnancy story on TikTok, which now has over , views in order to raise awareness of fertility struggles.She said: Being infertile and thinking you will be infertile are two drastically dferent things, but I would just encourage women to not give upthey want to become mothers, and to not take a doctoraposs words as the be all and end all. I donapost remember really coming across any relatable stories with my specic diagnosis during my pregnancy, so I hope this can be that to at least one woman.
