title: slemish celebrations are back for st patrick s day
story: Slemish Mountain and the award-winning village of Broughshane will welcome thousands of visitors this St Patrick’s Day as the popular celebrationsto the area for the first time since .The traditional St Patrick’s Day climb of Slemish willon Thursday  March with a series of activities planned to make it a rewarding experience for all.Broughshane  District Community Association will provide the hub of the event in the village, with outdoor entertainment, including performances from the lively band, Ragaire, and the twenty-strong, Portglenone Comhaltas Group, traditional music and dance, street theatre, with crafts and face painting for the very young. It will be the first time since  that the traditional St Patrick’s Day celebrations will take place at Slemish following the outbreak of Covid-, with virtual events staged over the past two years.Mayor of Mid and East Antrim, Councillor William McCaughey, said: “St Patrick’s Day at Slemish and Broughshane is one of the most popular and best attended public events within the Mid and East Antrim Borough Council area with thousands attending it each year.“An exciting programme of history and culture has been put together for this event and I look forward to welcoming visitors to the area.”Chairman of Broughshane  District Community Association, Lexie Scott said: “We are absolutely delighted to be joining in the annual celebrations for Saint Patricks Day. We look forward giving the many visitors, who will come to climb Slemish, a very warm welcome to the village and the many retail opportunities it can offer.”The award-winning Naturally North Coast and Glens Artisan Market will attend for the first time, with over  stalls, offering visitors the unique market experience showcasing a wide range of artisan produce and high quality hand crafted goods. The one and a half kilometre walk at Slemish takes approximately one hour up and down and it is strongly advised that suitable clothing and strong footwear is worn. Sections of the short climb can be steep and slippery and might not be suitable for all. Don’t forget to pick up your climber’s certicate and medal back down in the village, though supplies are limited. There will be no parking at Slemish, Carnstroan Road or Carnstroan Lane, so a free park and ride service will operate from the former Michelin plant, Broughshane, just off the M.The shuttle bus to Slemish Mountain will run continually from am – :pm stopping in Broughshane village, so nobody will miss out on the free entertainment and shopping offers.This event has been supported by The Executive Office through Mid and East Antrim Borough Council’s Good Relations Programme.For further information and download a guide for the day visit www.midandeastantrim.gov.uk stpatricksday

title: have your say on council s performance improvement plan 2022 2023
story: MID and East Antrim Borough Council has launched a consultation on its Performance Improvement Planfor the   period – its annual plan to support continuous improvement in the delivery of council services.During the consultation period, which extends to  May , residents, businesses and community groups across the Borough are invited to review the draft plan and have their say on Council’s proposed improvement objectives.Covering six key areas, the proposed improvement objectives for   are: Growing the economy and creating jobs. Supporting the communities within the historic conservation area of Carrickfergus, contributing to the sustainability of the local economy. Supporting MEA’s citizens’ health and wellbeing by providing quality, inclusive play and recreation facilities, and promoting safe and responsible outdoor recreation. Improving infrastructure to encourage electric vehicle uptake in the Borough to reduce emissions and protect the environment for future generations. Creating an Autism Friendly Mid and East Antrim Borough Council. Improving customer engagement and service delivery by enhancing Council’s use of information technology.Mayor of Mid and East Antrim, Councillor William McCaughey, is urging residents, businesses and community groups to engage in the consultation and ensure their views are heard.“As a Council, our duty is matched by our strong desire to drive performance and continuous improvement in the service we provide to the people of Mid and East Antrim,” he said. “To do so, we rely very much on their feedback and, as such, welcome all comments and suggestions received through this consultation process.“Underpinned by our Performance Management Framework, our proposed improvement objectives for the   period align closely to Council’s key priorities within our Community and Corporate Plans.“Our improvements focus on the issues that are important to the people of Mid and East Antrim, helping to improve the quality of le for all. For the upcoming year, we will also continue to focus on recovery and adapting to the ‘new normal’, taking proactive measures to minimise any lasting negative implications from the Covid- pandemic.”For more information about the Performance Improvement Plan and to complete the consultation questionnaire online, visit: www.midandeastantrim.gov.uk performance-consultationA printable copy of the consultation publication can be downloaded from the Council’s website and can be requested in an alternative format, such as large print or another language, by emailing communications@midandeastantrim.gov.ukHard copy consultation questionnaires should be ed to: Corporate Performance Team, Mid and East Antrim Borough Council, - Bridge Street, Ballymena, BT EJ.The consultation survey closes at noon on  May .The final plan will be taken to Full Council for approval before being published by  June , as is the statutory requirement.

title: how green is your candidate why its so vital to quiz politicians when they ask for your vote
story: Green Party NI leader Clare Bailey pictured. FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueGreen Party NI leader Clare Bailey pictured.March   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailPoliticians are increasing recognising that immediate and decisive action on the climate crisis will not only influence votes — it will win votes.Indeed, for many Northern Irish voters, climate action will be one of the defining issues in the upcoming MLA elections in May.With these elections fast approaching, many candidates have already started leafleting and door-knocking. However, when a candidate knocks at your door, what questions should you ask them  More importantly, how do you know whether they are genuinely serious about what they propose To gain a deeper sense of the candidate’s knowledge and understanding of climate breakdown, begin the conversation in the context of the broader political landscape.There are currently two climate bills passing through the Northern Irish Assembly. These are subject to ongoing debates, reviews and amendments. Both bills have a target of net zero emissions. Yet while the Private Members’ Billaims for Northern Ireland to be net zero by , the Executive Billaims for .Read MoreClimate: ‘Supporting that Bill would have led to the loss of , jobs in the farming sector’ – Agriculture Minister Edwin PootsYou could therefore start by asking the following question: which bill do they support Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Given how both bills aim for Northern Ireland to be net zero, despite ying target dates, a good follow-up question would be to ask how their party hopes to achieve this. How will they get us there  What is their political strategy  What concrete steps will they take to help Northern Ireland reach net zero Northern Ireland is not only the last nation in western Europe to implement climate legislation, but we also rank th worst in the world for bioersity loss. Nature recovery is therefore integral to an ambitious climate strategy.It is therefore crucial to ask the candidate about how they plan to halt and reverse nature and bioersity loss. How will they promote regenerative agricultural practices  How will they create more spaces for nature  How will they prevent the decline — and potential extinction — of our valuable species and wildle There are also three sectors in Northern Ireland which could be uniquely affected by the climate crisis: agriculture, energy and transport. These three sectors are vastly dferent. However, what unies questions regarding the future of these sectors is the principle of ‘just transition’.‘Just transition’ is the idea that we should not moveto a low-carbon, environmentally-friendly economyit means sacricing justice or ‘fairness’. A just transition recognises that, whether it be people on low incomes or workers in the fossil fuel industry, no one should be left behind in the creation of a ‘greener’ society.To take energy as an example, fossil fuels like oil and gas remain the primary source of heat and power in Northern Ireland. We already know that fossil fuels are harmful to the environment, and they will not help us to reach climate targets. Beyond asking candidate about renewable energy systems, we must therefore go one step further.We need to ask candidates about how they will compensate for workers in polluting industries, who may find themselves without a job in a more sustainable world. What incentive schemes will they promote  How will they re-train or upskill iniduals  How will government invest in this The same is true for agricultural and transport sectors. Will there be grants or public goods for farmers who dedicate areas of land to rewilding or regenerative practices  Will there be further investment in public transport infrastructure, particularly in rural communities  How will government incentivise citizens to support ‘greener’ lestyle choices that are typically more expensive, like buying an electric car or fitting solar  at home Lastly, ask the candidate seeking your vote about what is important to you.Whether it be plastic pollution or food waste, this is an invaluable opportunity for you to ask the candidate about a specic topic that you care deeply about. This could be an ongoing problem in your local area, or a global issue which causes you concern.Raising more personal questions with candidates may subsequently elicit a more direct response from them.Elections are a rare opportunity for citizens to shape environmental policy, and focus political attention on the most defining issue of our generation: the climate crisis.Climate change will be related to every social issue on each political party’s manesto – from gender equality to healthcare.Voting for candidates who support ambitious environmental policy solutions is therefore arguably the most important action that citizens can take.Remember this when candidates come calling.Related topicsEdwin PootsClare BaileyClimate ChangeClimate BillMore On Edwin PootsFriends of the Earth: But more compelling is the awareness of how, just a few years ago, all of this valuable material was just dumped into holes in the ground.It’s a filthy business, but far less filthy than the alternative of landfilling the contents of our bins.Anyone who has lived near a municipal dump knows the stench, flies and rats which follow. The toxic nature of much waste means the sites are contaminated for generations, threatening groundwater and wildle.And yet,we all dump our waste into black bins, these sites must go somewhere. It is hypocritical for someone who refuses to recycle to object to a landfill site simply because it is close to their home, rather than close to someone ’s.As recently as , every year we sent , tonnes of municipal waste to landfill by last year that had fallen by %, even though the population increased in that period.Not all the reduction is because of recycling. Just over a decade ago no household waste was incinerated, but now , tonnes are sent abroad each year to be burned to make electricity.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up But recycling is the key explanation for the transformation. Driven both by legislative compulsion and growing public awareness of how we are polluting our world and wasting its resources, many people now put more into their recycling bin than into the black bin.Compostable and food waste is now collected separately and used for everything from garden compost to creating gas which can power lorries or make electricity.But what happens when the recyclable material leaves our homes  It is particularly hard to understand how the recyclable items put into blue bins or other comingled recycling bins — where all manner of materials are mixed — can be accurately sorted for processing.In an industrial estate in Mallusk, Bryson Recycling is where that process unfolds for much of the east of Northern Ireland. Bin lorries from five council areas — Belfast Antrim and Newtownabbey Ards and North Down Lisburn and Castlereagh, and Mid and East Antrim — arrive and leave in a constant stream.Mechanical rams push out each bin lorry’s contents into a hangar. A huge quarry shovel loads it onto a conveyor belt. Plastic bottles explode like fireworks as the vehicle’s heavy wheels drive over the material.The belt carries the waste into the deafening materials recycling facility . The process which follows is surprisingly labour-intensive, as well as using technology to separate the waste.First, a group of workers stand on a raised  and manually lt obvious contaminants from the conveyor belt.Secondly, the belt moves through screens designed to remove paper, which goes to a separate line.The third process involves a magnet that attracts steel cans, such as baked beans tins.That process is then reversed at the fourth stage as the remaining material is subjected to an eddy current that repels aluminium into a chute.The line splits into four conveyors which run through a sorting cabin — the fth stage — where a team of workers pick out materials by hand, aided by a prototype robot that recognises materials and lts then.The sixth stage sees plastics removed using optical sensors which recognise material based on how it reacts to light. A final process involves a worker again manually picking out recyclable items which have been missed.By this stage, more than % of the initial material has been removed. But it’s not perfect. I saw plastic bottles and paper dropping off the end after the final check.The conveyors move quickly and not even all the obviously recyclable material can be caught there is no time to explore items which look unclear. Small items such as bottle tops are particularly unlikely to be correctly identied, falling off the end of the line to be taken for incineration.There are two forms of contamination: material which is wrongly bundled together through the MRF-sorting process [such as plastic in bales of paper], and material which cannot be recycled at all at that facility and so is taken for burning.The contamination at the start of the process stems from a mixture of ignorance of ambiguous rules for what can be recycled in dferent council areas, and deliberate flouting of rules.Claire McCallum has been in the recycling business for two decades at Bryson. “We’ve probably seen nearly everything coming through the doors here,” she tells the Belfast .“We have an ongoing issue with nappies coming through, but also dead animals all sorts of things. We’ve had quite a lot of dead lambs.”Food waste in containers rots, both making the process of hand-sorting more unpleasant and contaminating the final material.What can the public do to help  “I think the best thing people can do is, rather than look at a certain type of material and think ‘oh, that can be recycled’, always check your local council website,” she says.“And the other thing is to ensure things are clean give them a quick rinse before recycling.”But the blue bin comingled recycling is only part of what happens at this facility. Bryson’s own-design vehicles move to another part of the site where no sorting is necessary because the materials have already been sorted manually as they were lted.It is this system Ms McCallum believes is the future.It produces far higher quality materials, almost % pure, rather than some plastic or metal inevitably ending up in a bale of paper. And it uses far less energy, unlike the vast electrical and mechanical demand of the MRF plant.There isn’t just an environmental benefit to the kerbside sorting. Counterintuitively, Bryson says it is also cheaper for ratepayers.“We have been looking at cost analysis and we have worked out thatevery household in Northern Ireland had wheelie boxes, it would save councils about £ million a year,” Ms McCallum says.The costs of sorting the material properly by hand are higher, but the processing costs signicantly less and produces materials which can be sold for a much higher price.So why were councils ever using blue bins  She suspects councils instinctively did so because they had been used to bins and bin lorries, and when told to recycle, they used what was familiar.When asked about this, a spokesman for Nilga, which represents councils here, said the issue was complex, but that the public should try to consume as little materials as possible and recycle the maximum quantity of what they do use.Bryson would like to see a single, consistent approach to recycling across Northern Ireland.Another benefit of improving the quality of recycled materials is that it makes it easier to sell to local firms and improves the quality of their products.Just % of MRF-sorted material stays on the island of Ireland for processing for kerbside-sorted material that figure is %.The high quality, low-contamination materials are not possible through an MRF facility, Ms McCallum says: “You can’t achieve that through recycling through a blue bin system.”Bryson’s plastic, paper and glass is recycled locally, supporting about  jobs and generating around £m a year.The paper is turned into moulded packaging like egg cartons and cup carriers by Huhtamäki in Dollingstown. Glass is melted in a Encirc’s furnace in Derrylin before being turned into bottles for Bailey’s, Bushmills, Fever-Tree, Bottlegreen and other leading drinks brands. Plastic is taken to Cherry Pipes in Dungannon where it is made into civil engineering and agricultural pipes.In one key area, Northern Ireland is now behind the Republic.Last year it became mandatory for recycling companies south of the border to accept ‘soft plastics’ such as the film lids to be recycled.Here that form of plastic makes up much of what still goes into landfill. It is not likely to be collected for recycling locally until .Dealing with waste is complex, but it can be over-complicated by government. For years, as the government prodded people to recycle and cut black bin collections, there was public grumbling.But public opinion has shted rapidly polling now finds public support for recycling.In the post-war decades it was a symbol of society’s growing wealth that a consumer could buy something new, use it for a while and then dump it in landfill because a newer model was available or a minor fault had developed. But that materialistic hedonism has become increasingly uncool.Now people want to recycle more, and do so more easily, but it is government that has not moved to satisfy this desire — either by not collecting basic items such as soft plastic or glass for recycling, or by using a system that will inevitably fail to recover a high percentage of what could be salvaged, and will inevitably contaminate even what is recycled.Stormont and our councils have the power to change this — but may only do sothey believe votes are at stake.Related topicsClimate ChangeMore On Climate Change‘A vegan managing director Parr RenewablesJohn BreslinMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailSteve Parr sounds genuinely excited about his company’s new venture into the world of energy efficiency.The managing director of the Parr Group, the company he helped found more than  years ago, was speaking about the addition of a new arm to the Belfast-based construction and facilities management firm.Parr Renewables will join the Parr Group and Parr Facilities Management, a £m investment that will create more than  jobs, the company said.Its aim is to collaborate with colleagues across the Parr teams to deliver tailored sustainable energy solutions alongside the building, facilities management and specialist services already provided to customers across the UK and Ireland.The decision to establish the separate but linked arm to the company was driven by conversations with clients over the last year.What we were noticing with the cost of energy rising, everybody wants renewables, says Steve.They are all speaking about smart packs, solar, car charging.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up He cites the example of solar , saying the demand was not so great even a few years ago but has noticeably increased in the last six months while the costs of the  have fallen.His colleague, Richard Livingston, one of those new hires who will direct sales for Parr Renewables, adds:  A lot of people are looking at their spendings  —  and they want to future proof their buildings. And the predictions, including from the Utility Regulator here, are that high energy prices will be here to stay for quite some time.Prices had already been going up.  But the chaos created by the Russian invasion of Ukraine has added to the uncertainty with oil prices soaring due to concerns over the reliability of supplies. Brent Crude reached a -year high of nearly  US dollars per barrel on Thursday, while the prices of petrol and diesel have been hitting record highs.There was some talk among company management at Parr Group of a dedicated renewables unit over the last few years.But the decision was cemented within the last six months to a year.The Parr organisation, which began out of Belfast in  with five employees, has now grown into a multi-million businesses with offices also in Dublin, Manchester and most recently Glasgow.At the beginning, it was solely in the business of manufacturing but expanded with the addition of facilities management in . It also provides other specialist services. Its workload ranges from contracts worth over £m to inidual shop-fits, and its client base ranges from multinationals to smaller private clients.Clients of its fit-out services have included retailers like Hugo Boss and Swarovski.It posted revenues of £.m in , down from more than £m in , but in a dficult year. Its pre-tax profits increased to £,.The new arm will work with existing  —  and new  —  customers across Ireland and the UK to add renewable energy options while also working on construction projects with in built-plans for the use of renewables, including social housing projects here in Northern Ireland.Work will include new builds, refurbishments, modications, rewires and upgrades.Around  new people will come on board and most will receive specialised training.Steve maps out his vision of how Parr Renewables will fit in to the overall organisation. “It is not just about adding, for example, a solar element to the energy mix, though that is important —  it is much wider that that,”  says Steve.It is about the entire fabric of a building, from u PVC, smarts packs and plugs to car charging, window tinting on a sun facing rooms to cut down on air conditioning and a focus on proper insulation, he says.But solar is important and Steve believes the technology is available right now to capture and, crucially, store enough for it to be entirely viable.While it may not be suitable for all builds, specically apartments, it will be an important part of, for example, social housing.The organisation already operates in the social housing sector here, which is taking the lead on introducing a renewable energy element to new builds and modications.But this side of the border is behind efforts in the Republic of Ireland, where all new social housing building must have a renewable element, and there are grants available for that purpose from the government.“We do not have that here, Steve says.Parr#s decision to set up the new arm is part of the overall drive for much more energy efficiency along with switching from fossil fuels to renewables.But it is likely to be a dficult road, particularly when it comes to  electric vehicles, as there is not the infrastructure available to match demand.There is simply not the capacity to accommodate a wholesale switch.Steve cites the example of a major distribution centre where his company installed  EV chargers but all are not in use right now due to the lack of capacity.“The launch of Parr Renewables comes at a time when an increased uptake in renewable energy has never been more vital,” adds  Richard.With the recent surge in fossil fuel prices alongside the targets set for reducing carbon emissions, businesses are facing incredibly challenging times.“We’d already experienced a signicant increase in enquiries from existing customers on what measures they could take to improve their energy efficiency. title: time to fix the climate at any cost
story: Storm Eunice FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueStorm EuniceMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailClimate scientists are unambiguous about the need for rapid reductions in carbon emissions to meet the aim of limiting average levels of global warming to . degrees Celsius.While the climate challenge has been recognised for years, a lack of action up to now ramps up the urgency to act. It is now two years since the Northern Ireland Assembly declared a climate emergency. Similarly, Belfast City Council declared a climate emergency in October .Across Northern Ireland, the average annual land temperature in the decade - was .°C warmer than the period from the mid-s to mid-s. The st century has so far been warmer overall than any of the previous three centuries. Winter  was the third warmest winter for Northern Ireland since .The changes in climate that we are already experiencing are projected to continue and intensy. In the second half of the century, the amount of change that occurs will depend strongly on how successful we are in reducing greenhouse gas emissions globally.Annual temperatures in Northern Ireland are projected to rise by approximately .°C by the s from a - baseline average. Risks associated with rising temperatures, such as more extreme heatwave events causing impacts on people’s health, are likely to become more prevalent as a result of these projections, with their magnitude depending on the degree of change that is experienced.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up At the time of writing, Northern Ireland remains without a climate bill, although the expectation is that this will soon be resolved. The Department of Agriculture, Environment and Rural Affairs , led by Environment Minister Edwin Poots, and Green Party NI leader Clare Bailey have bills that have reached the consideration stage in the Assembly.Whichever bill emerges, it is clear that signicant change to our socio-economic model needs to occur to reach any of the proposed targets. In , Northern Ireland’s greenhouse gas emissions were estimated to be . million tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent. Northern Ireland accounted for % of UK greenhouse gas emissions in , compared to approximately % of the UK population. Agriculture , transportand residential buildingswere the largest sectors in terms of emissions. Mindful of the need to address this and maintain a viable economy, Daera has produced a draft green growth strategy which is about creating more green jobs and protecting or re-purposing existing jobs where possible.An important part of the draft green growth strategy is the new energy strategy from the Department for the Economy. It notes an ambition to deliver energy savings of % from buildings and industry by  and meet at least % of electricity consumption from a erse mix of renewable sources by .While the legislation may be edging forward and strategies are emerging, the current Northern Ireland report within the latest UK Climate Change Risk Assessment makes for sobering reading. The Government is required by the Climate Change Act  to conduct such an assessment every five years to inform the UK National Adaptation Plans for England, Scotland, Northern Ireland and Wales. The assessment covers  specic risks and opportunities in detail across themes such as infrastructure, health, the natural environment, international dimensions and business and industry.Taking the business and industry theme, issues such as increased flooding of business sites, increased levels of coastal flooding, access to finance, worker productivity and disruption to supply chains could all be at risk from climate change.For example, the annual bill for damage for non-residential properties in Northern Ireland is expected to increase by % by  due to flooding events. The expected annual damages for UK business properties from coastal flooding is expected to increase by % by .The Climate Change Risk Assessment also suggests that there is a risk that access to finance, investment, insurance, and capital for businesses are negatively impacted by climate change through decline in availability and affordability of insurance, a reduction in the value of assets and investment and increased credit risks and cost of capital.Across Northern Ireland, this is currently a medium risk, but it has the potential to rise to high magnitude in future.With these potential risks fast approaching, finding a path to net-zero is crucial. The net-zero carbon roadmap produced for Belfast is enlightening in this regard. Currently, % of Belfast’s emissions come from the domestic housing sector, with transport responsible for % of emissions, public and commercial buildings for % and industry %.Belfast’s roadmap includes an assessment of the potential contribution of approximately  energy-saving or low-carbon measures.I don’t think anyone knows where the money is coming from to pay for these initiatives, but it may be the case that a slowness to act has brought us to the point where we can’t quibble on the cost.Andrew Webb is chief economist at Grant ThorntonMost ReadDoctor faces tribunal over ‘cover-up’ title: former commons leader calls for bercow to be expelled from labour party
story: Former speaker of the House of Commons, John Bercow  FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueFormer speaker of the House of Commons, John Bercow By Amy Gibbons, PA Political CorrespondentMarch   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailFormer Commons leader Dame Andrea Leadsom said John Bercow should be expelled from the Labour Party after he was found guilty of bullying allegations.The former Commons speaker, who has been branded a “serial liar” and banned from holding a pass to Parliament following an investigation into his conduct, switched from the Tories to Labour last year.Dame Andrea, who is the Conservative MP for South Northamptonshire, told Times Radio that Mr Bercow was “incredibly discourteous” to people, and Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer “must expel” him from the party.“I had pretty much frequent run-ins with him and I saw the way he treated other people,” she said.“I do believe it was unacceptable. And, actually, what is so awful about it is that the Speaker of the House of Commons is almost the sort of highest authority here, you know, he or she is responsible for behaviour in the House of Commons, responsible for the way that we run things here. And it’s just unacceptable.”I think Keir Starmer must expel John Bercow from the Labour Party. There’s no doubt in my mind.Dame Andrew Leadsom, former Commons leaderShe added: “I think Keir Starmer must expel John Bercow from the Labour Party. There’s no doubt in my mind.”Dame Andrea was Commons leader between June  and May . She has also served as business secretary, environment secretary, and economic secretary to the Treasury.She made the comments after Parliament’s Independent Expert Panelcalled Mr Bercow a “serial bully” and said he should never again be allowed a Parliamentary pass.The IEP said an inquiry by parliamentary standards commissioner Kathryn Stone upheld  allegations against Mr Bercow from three complainants, all House staff at the time, relating to the period  to .Mr Bercow appealed against the commissioner’s findings to the independent  but it upheld her verdicts without exception.The former Commons speaker defected to Labour last year, saying he regarded the Tories under Prime Minister Boris Johnson as “reactionary, populist, nationalistic and sometimes even xenophobic”.He had served as a Conservative MP for  years until he was elected speaker in . He stepped down from that role in .At the time he switched allegiances, he told the Observer: “I am motivated by support for equality, social justice and internationalism. That is the Labour brand.“The conclusion I have reached is that this Government needs to be replaced. The reality is that the Labour Party is the only vehicle that can achieve that objective. There is no other credible option.”The Labour Party has been approached for comment.
